Title: Starburster
Comment: Kept hearing things about this band but didn't listen to anything until this year when I saw them say they didn't give a shit about Oasis reuniting and I knew we were on the same page.

Title: Are You Looking Up
Comment:
I just discovered Mk.gee (solo and his work with Dijon) a month ago or so and it's been on repeat ever since.  80s vibe without being cheesy. The coolest guitar tone. This song is such a banger. 
And, go do a deep dive on his guitar tone. Who knew a tascam could sound like this.

Title: Fuck Me
Comment: This bangs

Title: clairbourne practice
Comment:
my knowledge of shoegaze bands stops around 1994, so i recently asked for some recommendations from the current scene. this was the best tip-off i got. 

i don't know (and no longer care) whether they're actually shoegaze or not, but they're fantastic and definitely remind me of 90s bands like drop nineteens, tsunami and of course my bloody valentine - while still sounding fresh.

Title: Love Takes Miles
Comment: I’ve listened to this album pretty much non stop since January.

Title: Passing Strangers - 2008 Remaster
Comment: It’s officially okay to be very late to discover an amazing electropop band if their biggest album came out before you were born. I was initially obsessed with “Vienna,” of course, but this is also great. SYNTHS!!

Title: ICH KOMME
Comment: An absolute banger from this year's eurovision song contest that was completely robbed

Title: Day of Judgment
Comment:
I was in the hospital, recovering from a deadly infection, and finally had the wherewithal to catch up on some music I had heard about in recent years.

Early this year, probably sometime in February, this song hit my ears in the wee hours of the morning, when the hospital looks and feels like a ghost town. I just instantly connected with it. I related to it. It comforted me.

Later, I discovered that they almost lost their lead guitarist in an accident a few years ago, and he had spent some time recovering in a hospital. That made it connect even more.

Title: Ms. Lauren
Comment: I just found out about this band this week but I'm already completely sold on them. As someone who grew up on early 2000s pop Punk I can say these guys perfectly nail the silliness of the genre while also just crafting some incredibly catchy tunes.

Title: Boots
Comment: I really dig this song since I saw the movie last Friday. I mean, maybe song is a weird way to put it but goddamned, the way to voice gets more frantic. It’s so haunting and unsettling but I really dig it

Title: Realistic Rabbit
Comment: I just discovered Guerilla Toss a month ago when that song with Stephen Malkmus dropped. They have that controlled chaotic energy of early Sonic Youth with cleaner production and tighter grooves

Title: When Is It Ever Different
Comment: Finally, a moment to sit in peace and listen to some wistful, slowly building instrumentals that eventually swell and build to remind you of a time when Powerviolence bands played in basements around Amherst.

Title: Stars - 2019 remaster
Comment: it's got that propulsive chugga-chugga train-like groove, and the kind of vibe to match your train window surroundings as the twilight darkens and you speed into the night

Title: City of New Orleans
Comment: I love Willie, I love this song. It reminds me of my dad. Yes, the harmonica is a little train-like so I guess that’s part of it. But it just evokes a lot for me and honestly, I probably have listened to this song while gazing out the window of a train.

Title: Workin' On Leavin' The Livin'
Comment: Modest Mouse are always good for vibes about the vast world in front of our eyes that we can’t touch

Title: Black And White Town
Comment: I remember listening to this song on a train out of my hometown, and realizing then it was a bit on the nose but feeling inspired to never go back.

Title: Let Go
Comment: One time the girl next to me on the train was crying on the phone with her boyfriend while looking out the window. It sounded like a terrible relationship. After she hung up, she wound up telling me how awful he is and how she’s wanted to break up with him for a while. I tried to give her advice and support, and then as soon as she had phone service again she called him back and they broke up. Anyway, trains are a great place for letting go! This song would’ve been a good soundtrack for it.

Title: Bike Cops
Comment: A few years back i listened to this song on repeat while taking a train from Barcelona to Madrid. I think I was like 5 days into my spain trip and the mood of the moment was very low and homesick. Anyways, it's incredible how much the Spanish countryside looks exactly like the American southwest.

Title: Hannah & Gabi - 2022 Remastered Edition
Album: It's a Shame About Ray (Expanded Edition)
Comment: I had to be true to myself and post the first thing that came to mind. This song literally has a line about looking "out the window of a train", and it's beautiful, and while Evan Dando was pretty, odd, and pretty odd, I think this whole album is a masterpiece.

Title: Teenage Kicks
Comment: So I am picturing that I am on the train TO something - the excitement is building and I am looking forward to meeting someone at the platform and starting the activity that the train is bringing me to. This song makes me feel nostalgic in a sad happy way. The way where I want to cry looking out the window because I am so happy to not be a teenager anymore while allowing myself to feel the happiness with knowing my whole life is still ahead of me

Title: America
Comment: If there’s a better song for this theme I don’t want to hear it.

Title: No One Knows My Name
Comment: For the pensive traveling vibes

I was a huge fan of Nas when I first got into hip hop then I felt like he stopped making interesting music. Then out of nowhere he dropped 6 back to back classics and cemented himself as rap's elder statesman, staying relevant in a way his peers and enemies have failed to achieve. The Kings Disease trilogy is an artist at the top of his game and in rotation for me a lot more than his friends old stuff

Title: The Car
Comment: I know Arctic Monkeys have gotten a lot of shit since A.M. but quite frankly I found their earlier stuff to be rather run of the mill. Alex Turner’s lyricism and voice always felt out of place and underutilized to me on the first few records. Their newer stuff just sounds less forced to me.

Title: NEW MAGIC WAND
Comment: I never gave Tyler a chance because of his noteriety around his lyrics and then started to get into him through the Flower Boy album. Now I absolutely love everything that has come since then but good god when I try to listen to any of his first albums I just cringe so much and can't get past it. I'm so glad he moved towards this sound but I have no idea if that is the general concensus or not!

Title: Pattern Recognition
Comment: I like Sonic Youth’s earlier stuff, but I really like their later stuff. Especially this album. I probably lost all cool cred. But I have to be true to myself!

Title: Save Your Generation
Comment: Of all the bands that got caught up in the mid 90s "sellout" frenzy, I don't think any band took it on the chin from the punk scene harder than jawbreaker. After they signed to geffen the kids who came to their shows would literally turn their backs to the stage anytime they played something off this major label record, which then ended up being the last they'd ever record. A shame because it's by far the best they ever released, and if those back turning Punks ever stopped to pull their heads out of their own asses they might have actually heard any of it.

Title: Don't Carry It All
Comment: Controversial take: their fancy, very highly regarded earlier albums are good but actually a little annoyingly pretentious, overwrought, and sometimes tough to get through (and I especially still don’t even understand Hazards of Love’s prog/opera/metal??? or whatever was going on there). But they nailed the vintage roots rock sound on this one. Cozy and just really solid, and the more straightforward lyrics are refreshing. It was on a major label and found a lot of mainstream success, which I’m sure the “actually I prefer their earlier stuff” crowd hated. (The albums that followed are also very good.)

Title: No Longer Making Time
Comment:
Early 90s Slowdive were very good, and would (eventually) be recognised as an extremely influential Shoegaze band, but they had a lot going against them - the UK music press hated them, their record label lost interest (in favour of the likes of Oasis), and the two singer/guitarists Neil and Rachel broke up just before their second album. 

There are definitely some amazing songs from that period, but when they reformed after 22 years apart they sounded calmer, more confident (now that they were finally getting their dues as scene legends), and more mature, plus the production was massively improved compared to the rather insipid production of the 90s albums. 

This track in particular is wonderful, and listening to the two exes duet on a song that reflects on time and relationships, many years on from the end of theirs, is very affecting (and makes me bawl pretty much every time that I listen to it).

Title: Shadow Self
Comment: The Britpop kids of the 90s are still going hard 30 years later. Their newer stuff if more mature and focused but still just as cool.

Title: Here Before
Comment:
This song is from 2005, but her last album was in 2014 and her first came out in the 1960’s. She was 60 years old when this album was released. 

I like all eras of her music, but I think the later albums are better. The early stuff is catchier/sweeter and the later stuff is ethereal but still human. She captures melancholy and nostalgia in a moving way.

Title: The Stargate [Tablet I]
Comment: I've seen "Hidden History of the Human Race" mentioned as their best album a million times... but come on! I know it's not the 'coolest' pick but we know their new album is the best one. By far! I really do I prefer their newer stuff

Title: Rowboat
Comment:
Obviously, the classic Cash stuff is great, and stands alone as a catalog to be proud of, but there was also lots of filler to sift through, a bunch of religious stuff, some corny tracks, and a few years missing due to druggz.

So when Rick Rubin found the disheveled old rebel hero, I think Johnny felt humbled, inspired, and maybe even a little scared, but I think he wanted to rebel one last time, and what better way than to cover a bunch of weird songs, and record them alongside some new takes on old standards. Moody songs. Darker songs. Songs outside of his comfort zone. Obscure songs like this Beck track from Stereopathetic Soul Manure.

It was refreshing. It felt like finding a new artist. And while the grips of death were slowly trying to drag him down, I don't think Johnny ever felt more free artistically. Reinventing himself was the perfect way to complete an epic career, with one last fun chapter. A celebration of life in the face of death.

Title: All the Way Live
Comment:
From 2018, but a lot of the vocals are sampled from a record made as an "after school hip hop project" by students of Carver High School in Chicago in 1983 - a more innocent time when you could rap about what your name is, whether you were currently doing a rap, and whether you were doing that rap on a microphone.

I've heard the original record and it's also pretty great, but the addition of the brass section takes it to another level. Pure joy!

Title: I'll Be Your Friend
Album: One Jug Of Wine, Two Vessels
Comment: Aiming for a song that: I’d be listening to at about the time this mix could be made, and that I’d interpret as happy by missing what the song is about as a young teen. Coke, like Diet Coke?

Title: When You Wake up Feeling Old
Comment: I was going for what I imagine was the general time period of this mysterious tape, which brought me to Wilco, as most thought experiments do.

Title: Sink to the Bottom
Comment: Good vibes for good times

Title: I Feel Fine
Comment: If I was making a happy mix at 14 this is the first song I'd think to include on it

Title: The Reasons
Comment:
How refreshingly joyous to hear dudes who are respected in the punk community, sing earnest songs about love, companionship, and gratitude. As David Letterman would say, "I'll take all of that you got!"

It's quite a simple song, but that's what makes it's effectiveness so impressive. Much like Eddie Vedder once sang, "It's already been sung, but it can't be said enough: 'All you need is love'."

It takes a special artist to make such popular sentiments stand out as fresh, genuine pieces that take you to other places, and times. Or maybe they're even powerful enough to remind you it's time to go back home... 

I suppose the best songs do both things.

Title: Sunny
Comment: Listening to this on your Walkman while rollerskating on a warm and breezy day

Title: Hold On
Comment: legendary mood-booster from the cassette era, no explanation needed

Title: Hakuna Matata
Artist(s): Nathan Lane, Ernie Sabella, Jason Weaver, Joseph Williams
Comment: I don’t think a Happy Mix should not have this OR AT LEAST ONE DISNEY SONG on it. And if you think it’s lame to put a Disney song on a Happy Mix, well, I’m sorry for your loss.

Title: She Moves In Her Own Way
Comment: This is one of those songs that when it plays you can sing along and instantly cheer up or when you're already happy it just hits perfectly. And 2006 feels like the perfect time for this cassette!

Title: Yes - Full Version
Album: The Sound Of McAlmont And Butler
Comment: A big loud stirring declaration that yes we're doing better!

Title: Omen
Comment: Keith Flint died in early 2019 and it felt like everyone moved on very quickly... now I think Covid did overshadow everything when the band had announced they were going to continue and then when they began touring again after Covid it just felt like the world was super quick to accept that the shows would still be the same without him. An iconic frontman who most certainly has not made it to the pantheon of famous dead people

Title: Mighty K.C.
Comment:
I was very close to picking Sean Price, one of the greatest MCs to ever live, and far too often overlooked, but then I remembered a song that I have always loved, that comes along with an insanely sad story, and I knew I had to share it with you:

The year is 1995. An upstart rock outfit heavily influenced by REM and grunge, starts picking up steam. This culminates with For Squirrels signing a major label deal with Sony. In October, the album comes out, and by January of 2006, this thoughtful tribute to Kurt Cobain, is getting decent airplay on college radio, eventually reaching #15 on the modern rock charts.

I immediately loved this when they aired it on 120 Minutes, and was immediately bummed to discover that the lead singer, and bassist were killed in a tour van accident back in September of 2005, a month BEFORE the album dropped.

The other members played on, but it was ultimately impossible to overcome half their soul being removed on the brink of their introduction to the world.

Title: Somebody Made For Me
Comment:
Known as the ‘one-man Beatles,’ Emitt Rhodes wrote, produced, and performed every instrument on his first three albums. During the famed ‘Paul is Dead’ conspiracy, some even speculated he was brought in to record ‘Paul’s’ vocal parts. 

Unfortunately, Rhodes’ signed a bad deal. His contract with Dunhill Records demanded an album once every six months, an obligation Rhodes was unable to fulfill due to his time consuming DIY recording style.

Rather than work with Rhodes’ schedule, Dunhill decided to sue him for $250,000 citing a breach of contract. The trial effectively killed his career. Silent for 43 years, Rhodes released his fourth and final proper solo record in 2016 before passing in 2020. 


RIP Emitt Rhodes. You are forever in my pantheon of famous deads.

Title: Fool's Gold
Comment:
Lhasa was a rare talent and she died from cancer entirely too young at 37. She wrote and sang music in three languages. I love her deep and emotive voice. 
While I’m partial to the first album, this song is from the album she recorded while battling breast cancer. This last album was released less than 9 months before she died. 

This song has a beautiful sound and crushing lyrics.



She has a surprising amount of listeners, but I’ve never met anyone in person who has heard of her, so I wouldn’t say she’s a famous dead.

Title: The Losing End Again
Comment: Possibly best known (but still not, like, famously known like a Famous Dead) for playing guitar in Ryan Adams’ band for several years. Also a member of Beachwood Sparks and worked with pretty much all the big names in “Americana/roots rock/alt-country”/whatever we’re calling it. Only 50 when he died in 2019.

Title: Frightened By The Sound
Comment: Not the most famous of dead singers but always come back to him.

Title: Slip Inside This House - Stereo LP Version
Comment: Hard to imagine Rocky not making it into the pantheon but it’s a good jam

Title: Slow Death Hymn
Comment: Mischief brew singer Erik Peterson is the patron saint of anarchist coffee shops. He never really got famous, arguably intentionally so, but mischief brew deserves all the credit for elevating folk punk to an actual poetry. Erik died in his sleep shortly after this album was released.

Title: Hey Sa-Lo-Ney
Comment:
Rachel Nagy was the singer for The Detroit Cobras until her death in 2022 at the age of 48. Almost their whole output was cover versions, but mostly of forgotten gems (like this one) from the 50s and 60s. 

An incredible singer and a very sad loss, but a fantastic legacy of recordings - which, in her own words, is "a body of material that you can either go fuck your boyfriend or clean the house or whatever and not worry about skipping through songs”.

Title: Train in Vain (Stand by Me) - Remastered
Comment: Joe Strummer died at only 50, and while the Clash are legendary, I don't feel like Strummer is talked about in the legends we've lost lists enough even though he was a fucking titan.

Title: Frances Farmer Will Have Her Revenge on Seattle
Album: In Utero, In Tribute: A Tribute to Nirvana's In Utero, In Entirety
Comment: Here’s the late Jay Reatard covering the late Kurt Cobain

Title: Trouble in River City
Comment: One of my favorite ergs songs. And of course Mikey ergs has gone on to play in every band under the sun since then

Title: The Glamorous Life
Comment: Legendary drummer/percussionist for many big names and also a singer and artist with her own albums. This very 80s song was written and co-produced by Prince. Obviously, the drums are also great. Am I doing the prompt right? If not, at least you’re getting a cool song and someone with an impressive discography to learn about. And it’s less obvious than a Ringo song or Phil Collins song or something, eh?

Title: Ophelia - Concert Version
Comment: Levon Helms was the best to ever do it. There are countless performances that prove this, but the live version of Ophelia checks the 'complicated and impressive' box for me, especially when considering how his vocal melody weaves in and out of the drum parts. If you think the beat is simple, I implore you to zone in on the kick, because good god that man had groove for days.

Title: Supertoys
Comment:
Carla Azar is just one of the best drummers around, and sometimes does vocals as well for her band Autolux. This track is a 50/50 split, with her taking the choruses. The first chorus doesn't actually hit until 1.25 (which is also the place where the drumming finds another gear), and then she has the majority of the vocals after that. 

(If you need proof of her singing & drumming this song at the same time, there's a great "From the Basement" live session on YouTube).

Title: Too Many Things
Comment:
Mila de la Garza, aka Linda Linda No. 4, is the drummer and the primary vocalist on this song. 
While I’m not sure if the drums count as complicated, it’s impressive she sings smoothly while simultaneously drumming. She’s also currently 14 years old (almost 15), which is… humbling 

I think these girls are badass - and obviously accomplished at a young age. I’m excited to see where they go!

Title: Will of Whispers
Comment:
I remember hearing Tomb Mold for the first time and thinking: Cool, solid death metal, heavy, tight. It goes with the territory that the drums are going to be impressive.

Then I found a live video. And holy shit, the drummer is doing all of the vocals! 

I can wrap my head around playing guitar and singing, but double-bass with all arms engaged on a beat completely separate from the vocal rhythm? Holy shit, the drummer is the singer!

Title: Blood On Our Hands (Album Version)
Album: You're A Woman, I'm A Machine
Comment: Had no idea the drummer was singing in this band until several years ago.

Title: Curl of the Burl
Comment: Brann Dailor is one of my absolute favourite drummers and the songs he sings for Mastodon tend to also be my favourites of theirs. Any excuse I can get to post something from this album tbh is a good thing for me so thank you for this round

Title: Come Home (feat. André 3000)
Comment: Anderson Paak does the vocals and the drums on his tracks and this is a cool little tune (with a bonus 3 Stacks verse too)

Title: What Else Is New?
Comment:
J Mascis has been known to jump on the drums periodically throughout Dinosaur Jr's run, especially in the fractured, middle years where Lou was gone, and Murph only played drums sparingly.

This is one of those very tracks, and not only is it one of their most underrated songs, but I love that we get a double dose of J drums here, as he plays a chilling timpani at the end, as the perfect conclusion to one of their most epic compositions to date.

I personally never tire of Mascis, but rock music could definitely use more timpani.

Title: The Primitives Talk
Comment: Alright, gonna drag out my Hella fanboy shit and recommend this Zach Hill track where the drummer made a solo album and it’s this psychedelic freak-out masterpiece. But every now and then it gets hooky and this song has been stuck in my head for 15 years so now I’ve passed the curse onto you

Title: Terrible Hands
Comment: It’s hard to pick a single favorite song, but I go back to this one a lot. I think this was from a “you haven’t heard of them” round. Love the vocals and how the sound feels both warmly nostalgic (for the 80s and the early 2000s at the same time) and brutally sad.

Title: Clarinet
Comment: Not sure which round this came from but I liked it enough that I added it into my main playlist and the opening guitar riff always catches my attention.

Title: The Pelican
Comment: It was hard to choose one song. I don't know if this was my favorite, and I know it's not the one that hit me the hardest, but I chose it because it's the one I've revisited the most since hearing it, and also because it reminded me to listen to this album, which I meant to do years ago.

Title: Blame It On Bad Luck
Comment:
I can’t name another Bayside song and I’d like to choose something less embarrassing like that cool Kneecap song, but my streams don’t lie. This was my 3rd most streamed song of 2024. 

There’s a lot of shit I went through (as has everyone…) and it was easy to “blame it on bad luck,” blame how I grew up, and just overall have that gross victim mentality. 
This song is about taking accountability for your past mistakes and taking responsibility for (changing) the rest of your life. 

I had a tumultuous couple years and a reflective 2024 and this song found me right when I needed it. 

Cliche, but that’s ok. 

P.S. This comment I saw on Reddit helps with the cringe I feel when looking back. They suggested putting the Seinfeld theme over your cringe memories.

Title: No Good
Comment:
We really need a redux of this round because there were too many good choices to pick just one. I went with the song I remember standing out most to me on the playlist I was listening to at the time. Looking back through the lists, this was it.

From our "Phone-a-friend" round in Season 4, submitted by Anthony de la Cruz.

Title: H.O.O.D
Comment: I don't think there is a single artist from a 'you probably haven't heard of them' round that has aged this well, and it's wild to think that until Hard 12 I had not heard of KNEECAP, but here we are.

Title: Honeybody
Comment: I don't remember who submitted this song when and for what round but my god do I listen to this song a lot and like to go "oh honey body" at random points in the day. Absolute banger that fully has entered my life in a huge way

Title: Getting Married Today
Comment: This was in a round about amazing vocals and once I heard this song, I couldn’t stop listening. Like, am I missing out on musicals? I can’t get over how great her vocals are. Like, holy shit. And such a fun song. This was brought forth by Pat Sully.

Title: Underwater
Comment:
I'm indebted to James Knapp for introducing me to this incredible band via a  "You probably haven’t heard of them" round. It was a couple of years ago, but it was my first and only choice for this prompt, an absolute no-brainer. (And they still only have 361 monthly listeners). 

I wouldn't judge you if you didn't listen to all 6 minutes of this, but I honestly don't think you'll regret it if you crank up the volume and fully give in to this big swirling psych-y soup of a song as it slowly builds from ominous beginnings into a raging crescendo.

I'm not going to give you a timestamp on this occasion, but the moment when the lead singer opens their throat and wails out the name of the song (I think) for the first time gives me goosebumps like nothing else.

Title: Last Good Growth
Album: Not Enough Time To Get Anything Halfway Done
Comment:
Boilermaker is one of the saddest cases of a band never blowing up, not only because they had serious chops, but because lead singer Terrin Durfey died of cancer in 2008, so if they ever do get theirs, he'll never get to experience it.

Some of the best post punk for my money. I think it's safe to say if you enjoy bands like Built to Spill, Grandaddy, Pinback, early Death Cab, Braid,  and the like, you'll probably be wondering where Boilermaker has been your whole life. 

Terrin had such a great voice, and the band was so smooth. I'm not gonna sit here and say they should have been bigger than Green Day, but I'm surprised they're not at least a household name in indie rock nerd circles.

I'm hoping this box set they put out this year helps. It contains pretty much everything they ever put out. So help spread the word if you enjoy it, and maybe we can get them at least a bit more well known.

Title: Line
Comment:
If you like Duster you should check out Downward.

slowcore for elder emos, with a shoegaze haze.

Title: Ace
Comment: If you like The Internet (or any solo stuff from Syd or Steve Lacy) you should listen to this!

Title: Frank, AB
Comment:
This is a toughie for me. I’m not sure who to equate this band to. 

So I’ll say that if you like Neutral Milk Hotel, you’ll like this band. It’s less instruments but the singer has a distinct voice and they’re great songs. I love this band. (I also know them but that honestly doesn’t matter).

Title: Don't Know How to Love
Comment: If you like that raw, stripped-back duo sound of The White Stripes or The Black Keys, but you could sometimes do with one to two fewer dudes involved, I give you - Mr Airplane Man. They are Margaret (vocals/guitar) & Tara (drums), and they have less than 0.5% of the listeners of those bigger bands, but are every bit as good if not better.

Title: Dance It Down
Comment: The Pool is essentially the spiritual predecessor to LCD Soundsystem. Not even in a 'oh both are new wavey dance punks' way but in a 'James Murphy basically stole the entire band's sound from the Pool' kind of way.

Title: Cha Cha
Comment:
If you like El-P or Missy Elliot you should check out Sophie Hunter. 
Cha Cha is a banger for playing while walking around and would be pretty awesome slow motion entrance music.

Title: Sandcastle Molds
Comment: Do you like Wilco? Do you especially like their songs that are mostly still grounded in soft folk or more muscular Americana, maybe with a solid pop hook, but also get just a little bit rhythmically off-kilter and incorporate a few unexpected experimental sounds? Are you okay if the lyrics aren’t going to be Jeff Tweedy caliber? If so, you just might really like Dutch Interior!

Title: Main Theme - From 12 Angry Men 1957
Comment: Upfront putting out vibes that I will a problem for the other jurors

Title: Martin Scorsese
Comment:
Last Caress, and I Saw Your Mommy seemed too on the nose. System Blower by Death Grips seems like something scared old white dudes would immediately turn off before they even knew what offended them. 

I opted for this gem, because it's underrated in its mad simplicity, and it sounds just unhinged enough to raise red flags, and lots of hilarious questions, probably. ("Man, this guy is REALLY into Scorsese, huh?"; "What do you think it sounds like when he hates someone?")

I also find it awesomely odd that this weird beat poem almost sounds like the accidental precursor to latter day British post punk.

Title: Tag Walls, Punch Fascists
Comment: there are no sections in this song that say that we should sometimes also hug fascists, therefore i would clearly be demonstrating that i am not sufficiently even-handed and balanced to be a good juror

Title: Kill All the White Man
Comment: What song did your coworker pick?

Title: Crimes
Comment: This should hopefully sound some alarms.

Title: Fantasy Baseball at the End of the World
Album: Fantasy Baseball at the End of the World
Comment: Given who I imagine the judge is in the current political climate, I imagine a song about hoping for the severe injury or death of a certain someone might not go so well.

Title: Goddamn Devil
Comment:
I literally do love this song. It’s incredibly nostalgic for me. Judge me all you want! (Which is the basis of this thing, I guess). 

Ugly Kid Joe giving the middle finger as the Statue of Liberty is a clear indicator that I would not take the legal system seriously. The fact that it’s got a swear and the Devil? It just really adds to the fun. Also, who would ever say that an Ugly Kid Joe song is their favourite song? Someone unhinged and unpredictable. I rest my case, Your Honors.

Title: Killing In The Name
Album: Rage Against The Machine - XX (20th Anniversary Special Edition)
Comment: I know some lawyers who would dig this song so I don’t know if this would get me rejected from a jury

Title: Rape Me
Comment: Presented without further comment

Title: Lawyers, Guns and Money
Comment: A (great) song that strongly communicates “I have terrible judgment and get into tons of legal trouble, I believe in subverting the justice system with violence and bribery and nepotism, and I’m inadvertently involved with a lot of crime, including probably the one this case is about.”

Title: Goodbye Earl
Comment: He had it coming

Title: Wonder Why
Comment: Just over a thousand monthly listeners

Title: Everyone Looks so Fine
Comment: The bass player of this band is my dad's golfing friend. They were a popular local band in the 90s and recorded an album that never got released until they regrouped in 2020 and released it and now play their middle-aged hearts out. 116 listeners

Title: Lo Que Pasó
Comment: 38 monthly listeners. How fucking cool is this track? Found it in a Less Than 1000 Listeners playlist and it's fire

Title: Chain Fight
Comment:
51 followers. 

I got introduced to some great different music from listening to The Best Show on WFMU. Scharpling has great taste. This is such a great tune.

Title: A Greener Shade Of Teal
Comment:
114 monthly listeners

Love the opening line "Is there a hex code for it? A greener shade of teal"

Title: Hexagon
Album: In the Hour of the Wolf
Comment: 113 monthly listeners. One day, my Spotify recommendations started leading me through the Chilean indie rock scene, and then somehow then I jumped to this 2010s band from Costa Rica whose lead singer has a Smashing Pumpkins tattoo (and you can definitely hear that influence). Not even sure if they’re still active, but the whole album is a great listen.

Title: Wild One
Comment: This was a really awkward listener threshold for me to hit, so here’s a band I play bass in that should have a billion listeners but only has like… 97 or something.

Title: I Went To Prison Once - Demo
Comment: 7 monthly listeners

Title: Wanderlust
Comment: 324 monthly listeners. I guarantee that they're the best Belgian synthpop trio you've ever heard. Yes, even better than The Dirk-Jan Hoogenboom Superkuhl Elektrolekker 3.

Title: Heartbroken Forever
Comment: Trans/Queer alt-indie bedroom pop by Vito Valera. I just found out they’re going through chemo, so in honor of their struggle please enjoy this jam. They have 800-something monthly listeners

Title: Switchblades
Comment:
1774 listeners/month. That's astonishing to me.

I believe I first heard this magical man rapping on a song with two other extraordinary, and highly underrated MCs, K-the-I??? and Sole, and soon thereafter started digging around for other stuff.

When I first heard this track, I was immediately drawn to it. The beat was super interesting, and his lyrics were great, and boastful but kind of comically, feeling tongue-in-cheek, due to the fact that he's talking shit about dumb things that other rappers tend to do. He also says the word "fuck" many times in the song, but makes fun of the fact that he's doing so, ala Ben Folds.

This is just quintessential, super ill, ignored by the mainstream hip hop, that I pray one day gets played on radios somewhere, because there are countless tracks like this, begging to inspire current and future weirdos who need other weirdos to listen to.
